trial_identification.studytitle: Pilot Study of the Effects of GC811007 Administration on Copper and Trace Metal Metabolism in Non-diabetic Subjects and Patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Pilot Study of the Effects of GC811007 Administration on Copper and Trace Metal Metabolism in Non-diabetic Subjects and Patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in adult males with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and non-diabetic subjects to measure the effects on urinary copper, zinc and iron excretion.

interventions.interventions: This was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial in adult males with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and non-diabetic subjects; the two groups were age-matched. Within each group, half received GC811007 2400 mg/day taken once daily for the six day treatment period before breakfast, supplied as 300-mg capsules; and half received placebo. After the screening visit, subjects resided at the study site for a 6-day baseline period and a 6-day treatment period, during which all food and beverages were provided and measured to control intake of dietary Cu and other trace metals.
interventions.comparator: Placebo was supplied as microcrystalline cellulose (Vivapur type 102) in opaque Capsugel gelatin capsules

primaryOutcome.outcome: change in urine Cu excretion as measured from: - 24-h urine collections throughout the baseline (diet only, Days 1-6) and treatment periods (GC811007 or placebo, Days 7-12)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Days 1-6 - baseline measurements; Days 7-12 - treatment periods

primaryOutcome.outcome: change in urine Cu excretion as measured from: - 2-h urine collections during the first 10-h of the baseline (Diet only, Day 1) and treatment (GC811007 or placebo, Day 7) periods
change in Cu excretion as measured from: 24-h fecal collections throughout the baseline (Diet only, Days 2-7) and treatment periods (GC811007 or placebo, Days 8-13)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Cumulative Cu excretion by both urine and fecal collections.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Daily measurements for 6 days (Diet only, days 1-6 = pretreatment) Days 7-12 Treatment periods (GC811007 or placebo)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Dietary copper intake compared with urine and fecal excretion

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Male patients with Type 2 diabetes, and non-diabetic healthy male subjects with normal glucose tolerance test; normal ECG; normal serum levels of iron and ferritin; willingness to participate in a residential study for 12 days
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Female Gender, abnormal GTT; abnormal ECG; Abnormal serum iron and ferritin; unable to participate in a 12 day residential study.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The study was designed to explore the effects of GC811007 on trace metal metabolism in patients with T2DM and healthy non-diabetic subjects; specifically we wanted to investigate the effects of GC811007 on trace metal urine and fecal excretion under carefully controlled dietarty conditions in order to calculate trace element balance over a period of 6 days. We hypothesised firstly that baseline urine copper excretion would be raised in T2DM indicative of raised whole-body copper status which is a pro-oxidant status, and secondly that treatment with GC811007 would increase urine and fecal copper losses, and engender a negative copper balance.
